unnormalised: New Delhi – Indian consumers are increasingly prioritizing fuel efficiency when purchasing vehicles, driven by rising petrol and diesel prices. Dr. Anjali Sharma, professor at IIT Delhi's Automotive Research Centre, notes that manufacturers are responding with improved engine technology and hybrid options.
normalised: New Delhi – Indian consumers are increasingly prioritizing fuel efficiency when purchasing vehicles, driven by rising petrol and diesel prices. Doctor Anjali Sharma, professor at I I T Delhi's Automotive Research Centre, notes that manufacturers are responding with improved engine technology and hybrid options.

unnormalised: Recent tests by ARAI show that the Maruti Suzuki Celerio AMT boasts an impressive 26.68 km per liter. This focus on mileage reflects a shift in consumer mindset, especially in price-sensitive markets like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.
normalised: Recent tests by A R A I show that the Maruti Suzuki Celerio A M T boasts an impressive twenty six point six eight kilometer per liter. This focus on mileage reflects a shift in consumer mindset, especially in price-sensitive markets like Uttar Pradesh and Bihar.

unnormalised: Beyond engine optimization, advancements in lightweight materials and aerodynamics are contributing to better fuel economy. Even electric vehicles are playing a role, with charging infrastructure slowly expanding across major cities.
normalised: Beyond engine optimization, advancements in lightweight materials and aerodynamics are contributing to better fuel economy. Even electric vehicles are playing a role, with charging infrastructure slowly expanding across major cities.

unnormalised: "Think of it like saving 'Rs. 50' on every '10 km'," explains auto journalist, Rohan Verma. "Over the long run, that adds up significantly!" The government's push for fuel-efficient vehicles, combined with growing consumer awareness, promises a greener and more economical future for Indian roads. The new Tata Nexon EV offers a parking assist feature and uses around 100 sq ft less space than a traditional SUV.
normalised: "Think of it like saving 'rupees fifty' on every 'ten kilometer'," explains auto journalist, Rohan Verma. "Over the long run, that adds up significantly!" The government's push for fuel-efficient vehicles, combined with growing consumer awareness, promises a greener and more economical future for Indian roads. The new Tata Nexon E V offers a parking assist feature and uses around one hundred square feet less space than a traditional S U V.
